Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Governance and Networks of Coordination in Community Diversion Programs

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Major American cities have responded to rising incarceration rates with creative alternatives, such as Drug Courts and Mental Health Courts. These alternatives often depend on complex networks that connect municipal governments, not-for-profit organizations, and private service providers. The research supported by this award will examine the functioning and effectiveness of these coordinated collaborations. In addition, the researchers ask what effects decentralizing government has on outcomes, both for communities and for system clients. This is critical information for all stakeholders seeking to lower incarceration rates.

The research will be undertaken in the city of Philadelphia by University of Pennsylvania anthropology doctoral candidate Tali Ziv, who is supervised by Dr. John L. Jackson, Jr. Philadelphia has been federally mandated to undertake efforts to reduce its large prison population. One response has been the Forensic Intensive Recovery (FIR) Program, a sentence reduction and community alternative program for substance abuse and minor mental illness. FIR engages two large nonprofit subcontracts and coordinates the jails, probation and parole, the courts, and nonprofit community based services; this makes it an ideal site for research on decentralized sentencing alternatives. The researcher will carry out ethnographic observations in the court room and in the community, document the daily work of FIR social workers, and interview judges, attorneys, counselors, clients, and criminal justice system representatives. In addition, she will collect data from archives to track the emergence of these novel institutional formations. Taken together, these data will allow her to understand the micro-processes through which coordination works, how the different layers of the criminal justice system and its community referrals build knowledge about one another, and what this means for understanding not only sentencing alternatives but also the nature of contemporary urban governance.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This investigation found that the subcontracted nature of this diversion network greatly affected the nature of the power it effectuated in the lives of its subjects. Individual case managers had an extraordinary influence on the outcomes of their clients as they were responsible for communication with probation officers who then made the unilateral decision to rearrest or bring a case back in front of the judge. In other words, the punitive power of the state was enacted with a remarkable lack of standardization and consistency that also involved the powerful discretion of individual judges. Many of these decisions were based on misinformation or a lack of coordination between the different players. Programs were often contacted on the phone by public defenders at the bar of court, desperate to ascertain what “really happened” with a client. 
         This investigation ended up spending far more time in the IOP and recovery house setting than expected, further analyzing the role that directors and counselors in these treatment facilities also play for justice involved clients. The private imperatives — such as completing a full round of outpatient treatment or maintaining a client on medication assisted treatment — had profound impacts on the course of substance abuse treatment for all clients, but less direct impact on justice-involved clients than anticipated. Individual relationships and clinical perspectives however played a serious role in which clients were given strong justice reports and those who were not. Furthermore, the capacity of the treatment center to advocate for the client in court by sending a representative or writing a strong letter of support varied greatly between the corporate and non-corporate centers and depended significantly on the individual counselor at hand.  
        Generally, these two insights led to my collaboration in a city run initiative aimed towards the coordination and centralization of justice related social service programs to enhance communication and standardization. I have also shared the more general finding to city actors that drug treatment practitioners largely recognize extreme poverty as the primary underlying factor  generating most of their clients’ drug use and criminal involvement. These individuals are desperate to help their clients secure housing and employment but simply lack the resources to do so. As a result, I am co-directing a collaborative effort to inspire the southeastern Pennsylvania public transit authority to distribute 10 free public transit rides a week to all reentering citizens leaving the city jails.
